results.title: Horsham Greyhounds
results.brief_description: Meet the people that work at the greyhound races every Tuesday afternoon at Horsham, in western Victoria. Mostly volunteers, they assist the dogs and their owners from vets checks to wash downs, ensuring that Horsham Greyhounds remains the safest race in Victoria.

results.title: Gil and Liz Hopkins
results.brief_description: Gil and Liz Hopkins have lived in Laharum, in western Victoria, for over 30 years. They raised three children there, built their own home, which is nearly completely self-sufficient, with solar panels and reclaimed water. Their hope is to leave the land in better shape than they found it and they’re taking their knowledge to the community to help others do the same.

results.title: The Gasifier
results.brief_description: Bill Gardner is tackling climate change in his own backyard, with the help of his mates John and Will. Together, these ‘Wimmera men’, located in western Victoria, are investigating the potential of using gasifier technology, which can be used to convert grain into fuel. Rather than being dismissed as ‘crazy’, this initiative has received widespread support from both the government and community.

results.title: Dave Jones and his Giant Puppet
results.brief_description: Dave Jones is an animator who moved to Natimuk about 2001, follow him as he works on an ambitious live projection project involving a 14 metre high puppet, which will be suspended from the town grain silos.

results.title: Clarrie's Ranch
results.creator_credit: Jessica Scott, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Clarence ‘Clarrie’ Mackley has built his own patch of paradise, a small ranch devoted to Slim Dusty, Elvis and all things country and western. Living by his ethos of ‘do what you wanna do’, Mackley attracts tourists from all over to the world to his colourful place in Horsham, western Victoria.

results.title: At the Foot of the Arapiles
results.brief_description: Meet the business owners and locals who call Natimuk home and wouldn’t want to live anywhere else. Even though locals consider it to be full of ‘climbers’ and ‘arty-types’, they recognise Natimuk, in western Victoria, as an active and diverse community and wouldn’t have it any other way.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Mansfield Shire
results.brief_description: ‘ACMI in the regions: stories from Mansfield Shire’ takes a look at the towns of Mansfield, Tolmie and Jamieson, located in north-eastern Victoria. Interviews with the locals provide a sense of the rich history of these towns and the lifeblood that keeps them thriving.

results.title: Why we luv Jammo
results.brief_description: A diverse cross-section of the “Jammo” community tell us why they’ve chosen this particular slice of heaven to call home. The post-mistress, the erstwhile town photographer, the caravan park operator and a handful of other locals, explain how they came to live in Jamieson (located in north-eastern Victoria) and how the peace, quiet and stunning natural beauty have convinced them there is really no better place to live. The rustling of the wind in the trees, native bird calls and tinkling waterways contribute a natural soundtrack which helps evoke this unique place.

group_siblings.title: Three stories of agriculture in Mansfield

results.title: Three stories of agriculture in Mansfield
results.brief_description: Living on the land requires innovation and imagination these days. Three dynamic operators from the Mansfield Shire, in north-eastern Victoria, talk about the various challenges and rewards of working in the region. From the high-tech, computer controlled Murphy Fresh hydroponic tomato farm, to the glorious grounds of Kinloch Winery and the generations-old Delatite Station: these modern day “farmers” reflect on their great fortune at being able to run their operations in such a rich and diverse community.

results.title: A Tale of two cinemas
results.brief_description: A cinema can be much more than a place to see movies, as this story of the old Mansfield Cinema, and its modern counterpart – the totally digital Mansfield Armchair Cinema – explores. When the old Mansfield Cinema closed down, the town lost its cultural centre. Years on, it took the brainwave of a local accountant and a lot of community support, to resurrect cinema in Mansfield, located in north-eastern Victoria. Building from strength to strength, Armchair Cinema is unique in that it was the first totally digital cinema in Victoria and it is almost exclusively run by teenagers from the local high school.
